content: The "Medicare Commission Act of 1996" may be cited as the short title for this Act. It establishes a commission. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program is established with 15 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders, with specific guidelines for political party representation among the members selected by the President and the Majority Leader of the Senate. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders. The Majority Leader of the Senate selects members from among Senate members and private citizens, with restrictions on political party affiliation. The Speaker of the House appoints five members from the House of Representatives and private citizens, with similar party affiliation limitations. Five members of the National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program are appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, in consultation with the Minority Leader, within 3 months of the Act's enactment. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program will have five members appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives within 3 months of the Act's enactment. Members will serve for the life of the Commission, and any vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The initial meeting must take place no later than 30 days after the appointment. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program will have five members appointed for life. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings will be called by the Chairman. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the Commission will select a Chairman from among its members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with reviewing analyses of the current and long-term financial condition of the Medicare trust funds, identifying potential threats to their solvency, and analyzing solutions to ensure the financial integrity of the Medicare Program and provision of health benefits. The Commission is responsible for reviewing the financial condition of the Medicare trust funds, identifying threats to solvency, analyzing potential solutions to ensure financial integrity, and providing recommendations to preserve long-term solvency. The Commission reviews the financial condition of the Medicare trust funds, identifies threats to solvency, analyzes potential solutions, and provides recommendations to preserve long-term solvency. The term "Medicare trust funds" refers to the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. The Commission reviews the financial condition of the Medicare trust funds, identifies threats to solvency, and provides recommendations to preserve long-term solvency. The term "Medicare trust funds" refers to specific funds established under the Social Security Act. The Commission's report is due within 12 months of its first meeting, and Congress will consider legislation based on its recommendations. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within 12 months of its first meeting. Congressional leaders will develop legislation based on the Commission's recommendations. The Senate and House leaders, in consultation with Minority Leaders, will draft legislation within 3 months of receiving a report to ensure Medicare trust funds' long-term solvency. If not voted upon, the legislation will receive privileged consideration. The Senate and House leaders must draft legislation within 3 months of receiving a report to ensure the long-term solvency of the Medicare trust funds. If not voted upon within 3 months, the legislation will receive privileged consideration. If legislation introduced in the House of Representatives is not voted upon within 3 months, the committee to which it was referred will be treated as having privileged consideration. If legislation introduced in the House of Representatives is not voted upon within 3 months, the committee to which it was referred will be discharged from consideration, and a motion to proceed with the legislation will be highly privileged. If legislation introduced in the Senate is not voted upon within 3 months, the legislation will be discharged from consideration, and a motion to proceed with it will be treated as highly privileged. If legislation introduced in the Senate is not voted upon within 3 months, it will be discharged from consideration, and a motion to proceed with it will be treated as highly privileged. If legislation in the Senate is not voted on within 3 months, it will be discharged from consideration, and a motion to proceed with it will be treated as privileged. If legislation introduced in the Senate is not voted on within 3 months, a motion to proceed with it will be treated as privileged. Legislation not voted on within 3 months in the Senate will be privileged for consideration. If not voted on in the House within the same timeframe, it will be highly privileged. This allows for a joint resolution endorsing report recommendations and providing legislative authority. The Commission is granted powers under Section 4. The Commission under Section 4 has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and utilize postal services as needed to fulfill the purposes of the Act. The Commission may request information from federal agencies and use postal services as needed to fulfill the purposes of the Act. SEC. 5. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission who are federal government officers or employees serve without additional compensation. Private citizens serving on the Commission also do so without compensation, with exceptions outlined in subparagraph (B). Private citizens of the United States who are members of the Commission serve without compensation, but are allowed travel expenses. Members of the Commission who are not federal government officers or employees are allowed travel expenses, including per diem, at authorized rates while performing services for the Commission away from their homes or regular places of business. The Chairman of the Commission may appoint staff. The Chairman of the Commission may appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide necessary administrative support. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint and terminate an executive director and other necessary personnel. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide administrative and support services. The Chairman can set the compensation without following civil service laws. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and other staff members, and set their compensation without following civil service laws. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint an executive director and staff with pay not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. The Chairman of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. Expenses will be paid from funds available to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
